issue.title: Bugs (UI and feature access) from incorrectly set config paths (macOS homebrew?)

labels.name: os:macos
labels.description: Issues specific to macOS operating system

issue.body:
## Description On [homebrew python installations on macOS](https://docs.brew.sh/Homebrew-and-Python), with `pip` installation of packages: * "Open in..." menu, extension manager and extension UI all don't show up correctly. * Seems to be related to locations of config files. There are also related bugs specific to: * [notebook 7 — see this issue](https://github.com/jupyter/notebook/issues/6974) (This has a [full list of all related symptoms](https://github.com/jupyter/notebook/issues/6974#issuecomment-1659117884).) * [nbclassic — see this issue](https://github.com/jupyter/nbclassic/issues/255) Basically, with homebrew python, `jupyter --paths` _should_ have: * `/opt/homebrew/etc/jupyter`in "config" and * `/opt/homebrew/share/jupyter` in "data" This can be done by hand with `JUPYTER_PATH=/opt/homebrew/share/jupyter JUPYTER_CONFIG_PATH=/opt/homebrew/etc/jupyter`. (or homebrew should somehow populate the default directories with the contents that it places in those locations). Note also that the config homebrew directories that _does_ appear in `jupyter --paths` — `/opt/homebrew/opt/python@3.11/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/3.11/etc/jupyter` — does not exist. The data dir `.../share/jupyter` exists (perhaps only after `jupyter build`?) but is different from `/opt/homebrew/share/jupyter`. (I don't know if this is unique to macOS — there is also linux homebrew — or indeed if this could be a broader issue, but I've only seen it for this one case.) ## Reproduce In the "base" homebrew python environment (i.e., no venv, and also not the system python), with `jupyter lab`: * the "Open in..." menu does not appear * the "Installed" extension list is empty and, for example, there is no sidebar entry for ipyparallel even when installed: The problem disappears with `JUPYTER_PATH=/opt/homebrew/share/jupyter JUPYTER_CONFIG_PATH=/opt/homebrew/etc/jupyter`. ## Expected behavior When run with those variables set, or in a venv, these issues go away. In particular: ## Context - Operating System and version: macOS 13.5 with homebrew. - Browser and version: Safari 16.6 - JupyterLab version: 4.0.3 - Notebook version: 7
`jupyter --paths` 
config:
    /Users/jaffe/.jupyter
    /Users/jaffe/Library/Python/3.11/etc/jupyter
    /opt/homebrew/opt/python@3.11/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/3.11/etc/jupyter
    /usr/local/etc/jupyter
    /etc/jupyter
data:
    /Users/jaffe/Library/Jupyter
    /Users/jaffe/Library/Python/3.11/share/jupyter
    /opt/homebrew/opt/python@3.11/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/3.11/share/jupyter
    /usr/local/share/jupyter
    /usr/share/jupyter
runtime:
    /Users/jaffe/Library/Jupyter/runtime

comment.body: FWIW, and as expected, all of these errors and misbehaviours vanish for the python.org framework build (of 3.12, but I assume more generally), without requiring any special environment variables or other changes. This still lets me install packages by pip and not be wedded to using a venv, so I think I am moving back to this infrastructure from homebrew, at least for now.

issue.title: Bugs (UI and feature access) from incorrectly set config paths (macOS homebrew?)

labels.name: os:macos
labels.description: Issues specific to macOS operating system

issue.body:
## Description On [homebrew python installations on macOS](https://docs.brew.sh/Homebrew-and-Python), with `pip` installation of packages: * "Open in..." menu, extension manager and extension UI all don't show up correctly. * Seems to be related to locations of config files. There are also related bugs specific to: * [notebook 7 — see this issue](https://github.com/jupyter/notebook/issues/6974) (This has a [full list of all related symptoms](https://github.com/jupyter/notebook/issues/6974#issuecomment-1659117884).) * [nbclassic — see this issue](https://github.com/jupyter/nbclassic/issues/255) Basically, with homebrew python, `jupyter --paths` _should_ have: * `/opt/homebrew/etc/jupyter`in "config" and * `/opt/homebrew/share/jupyter` in "data" This can be done by hand with `JUPYTER_PATH=/opt/homebrew/share/jupyter JUPYTER_CONFIG_PATH=/opt/homebrew/etc/jupyter`. (or homebrew should somehow populate the default directories with the contents that it places in those locations). Note also that the config homebrew directories that _does_ appear in `jupyter --paths` — `/opt/homebrew/opt/python@3.11/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/3.11/etc/jupyter` — does not exist. The data dir `.../share/jupyter` exists (perhaps only after `jupyter build`?) but is different from `/opt/homebrew/share/jupyter`. (I don't know if this is unique to macOS — there is also linux homebrew — or indeed if this could be a broader issue, but I've only seen it for this one case.) ## Reproduce In the "base" homebrew python environment (i.e., no venv, and also not the system python), with `jupyter lab`: * the "Open in..." menu does not appear * the "Installed" extension list is empty and, for example, there is no sidebar entry for ipyparallel even when installed: The problem disappears with `JUPYTER_PATH=/opt/homebrew/share/jupyter JUPYTER_CONFIG_PATH=/opt/homebrew/etc/jupyter`. ## Expected behavior When run with those variables set, or in a venv, these issues go away. In particular: ## Context - Operating System and version: macOS 13.5 with homebrew. - Browser and version: Safari 16.6 - JupyterLab version: 4.0.3 - Notebook version: 7
`jupyter --paths` 
config:

    /Users/jaffe/Library/Python/3.11/etc/jupyter
    /opt/homebrew/opt/python@3.11/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/3.11/etc/jupyter
    /usr/local/etc/jupyter
    /etc/jupyter
data:

    /Users/jaffe/Library/Python/3.11/share/jupyter
    /opt/homebrew/opt/python@3.11/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/3.11/share/jupyter
    /usr/local/share/jupyter
    /usr/share/jupyter
runtime:
    /Users/jaffe/Library/Jupyter/runtime

comment.body: FWIW, and as expected, all of these errors and misbehaviours vanish for the python.org framework build (of 3.12, but I assume more generally), without requiring any special environment variables or other changes. This still lets me install packages by pip and not be wedded to using a venv, so I think I am moving back to this infrastructure from homebrew, at least for now.

issue.title: Bump yarn to 3.6.4

milestone.description: Milestone to track issues that will be released with JupyterLab 4.1.0.

issue.body:
<!--
Thanks for contributing to JupyterLab!
Please fill out the following items to submit a pull request.
See the contributing guidelines for more information:
https://github.com/jupyterlab/jupyterlab/blob/main/CONTRIBUTING.md
-->

## References

<!-- Note issue numbers this pull request addresses (should be at least one, see contributing guidelines above). -->
Maintenance to bump to the latest Yarn v3+

I stayed away from the new [v4](https://yarnpkg.com/blog/release/4.0). We may try it after JupyterLab 4.1
<!-- Note any other pull requests that address this issue and how this pull request is different. -->

## Code changes

<!-- Describe the code changes and how they address the issue. -->
Bump vendored yarn to 3.6.4

## User-facing changes

<!-- Describe any visual or user interaction changes and how they address the issue. -->
None
<!-- For visual changes, include before and after screenshots or GIF/mp4/other video demo here. -->

## Backwards-incompatible changes

<!-- Describe any backwards-incompatible changes to JupyterLab public APIs. -->
None

comment.body:
> Something else to note here - with immutable builds the downstream extensions will need to refresh lock files after updating JupyterLab (even if they don't bump any npm dependencies). Not a huge pain but I saw reports of "this lockfile is different for me locally" because an earlier point release of yarn was shipped in JupyterLab RC phase.

Yes the reason for it is the yarn typescript patch; I wished it was not needed or somehow they don't complain about the version in the lock file as it is builtin within yarn.

I'll add a note in the migration guide.

issue.title: Fix autobrackets and other default CM extension

milestone.title: 4.0.x
milestone.description: Track issues than can be fixed and released in a post 4.0 release.

issue.body:
<!--
Thanks for contributing to JupyterLab!
Please fill out the following items to submit a pull request.
See the contributing guidelines for more information:
https://github.com/jupyterlab/jupyterlab/blob/main/CONTRIBUTING.md
-->

## References

<!-- Note issue numbers this pull request addresses (should be at least one, see contributing guidelines above). -->
Fixes #14559

looking at the [basic setup](https://github.com/codemirror/basic-setup/blob/b3be7cd30496ee578005bd11b1fa6a8b21fcbece/src/codemirror.ts#L69) from CM, this adds also:
- [highlightSpecialCharacters](https://codemirror.net/docs/ref/#view.highlightSpecialChars)

There is one I'm unsure about:
- [highlightSelectionMatches](https://codemirror.net/docs/ref/#search.highlightSelectionMatches)

I'm not confident about that one as it won't work for notebook (only for file editor). And I guess the LSP extension as something better for it.

cc @krassowski

<!-- Note any other pull requests that address this issue and how this pull request is different. -->

## Code changes

<!-- Describe the code changes and how they address the issue. -->
Add CM extensions: `closeBracketsKeymap`, `highlightSpecialChars`

## User-facing changes

<!-- Describe any visual or user interaction changes and how they address the issue. -->
- Backspace between two brackets deletes both if auto closing option is on
- [Special characters](https://github.com/codemirror/view/blob/e6a55a6515521a84e709f02b4eb32e57aebbbfba/src/special-chars.ts) will now be highlighted with red dots, e.g. `­؜​‎‏  `

Before
![Screenshot from 2023-10-26 21-51-01](https://github.com/jupyterlab/jupyterlab/assets/5832902/751993e9-6897-4fb0-8846-ac9cd8485870)

After
![Screenshot from 2023-10-26 21-51-08](https://github.com/jupyterlab/jupyterlab/assets/5832902/2ee7b9e7-d357-4b7e-b5f3-4400fddb2c6d)


## Backwards-incompatible changes

<!-- Describe any backwards-incompatible changes to JupyterLab public APIs. -->
None

issue.title: Deleting brackets with auto-close-brackets enabled only deletes one of the brackets (jupyterlab 4.0)

labels.name: tag:Regression
labels.description: Behavior that had been broken, was fixed, and is broken again

milestone.title: 4.0.x
milestone.description: Track issues than can be fixed and released in a post 4.0 release.

issue.body:
## Description

As in the title, deleting brackets with auto-close-brackets enabled in jupyterlab 4.0, only deletes one of the brackets. In previous verions deleting brackets/parenthesis/braces deleted both. 

## Reproduce

Deleting brackets/braces/parethesis in jupyterlab 4.0.

## Expected behavior

Deleting one of the brackets with auto-close-brackets enabled should delete both as in previous versions of jupyterlab.

## Context

- Operating System and version: Linux mint 21.1
- Browser and version: firefox 113
- JupyterLab version: 4.0.0

commits.message:
Fix autobrackets and other default CM extension (#15297)

* Fix auto-closing bracket deletion

* Add highlight special characters

pull_request.title: Fix autobrackets and other default CM extension
pull_request.body:
<!--
Thanks for contributing to JupyterLab!
Please fill out the following items to submit a pull request.
See the contributing guidelines for more information:
https://github.com/jupyterlab/jupyterlab/blob/main/CONTRIBUTING.md
-->

## References

<!-- Note issue numbers this pull request addresses (should be at least one, see contributing guidelines above). -->
Fixes #14559

looking at the [basic setup](https://github.com/codemirror/basic-setup/blob/b3be7cd30496ee578005bd11b1fa6a8b21fcbece/src/codemirror.ts#L69) from CM, this adds also:
- [highlightSpecialCharacters](https://codemirror.net/docs/ref/#view.highlightSpecialChars)

There is one I'm unsure about:
- [highlightSelectionMatches](https://codemirror.net/docs/ref/#search.highlightSelectionMatches)

I'm not confident about that one as it won't work for notebook (only for file editor). And I guess the LSP extension as something better for it.

cc @krassowski

<!-- Note any other pull requests that address this issue and how this pull request is different. -->

## Code changes

<!-- Describe the code changes and how they address the issue. -->
Add CM extensions: `closeBracketsKeymap`, `highlightSpecialChars`

## User-facing changes

<!-- Describe any visual or user interaction changes and how they address the issue. -->
- Backspace between two brackets deletes both if auto closing option is on
- [Special characters](https://github.com/codemirror/view/blob/e6a55a6515521a84e709f02b4eb32e57aebbbfba/src/special-chars.ts) will now be highlighted with red dots, e.g. `­؜​‎‏  `

Before
![Screenshot from 2023-10-26 21-51-01](https://github.com/jupyterlab/jupyterlab/assets/5832902/751993e9-6897-4fb0-8846-ac9cd8485870)

After
![Screenshot from 2023-10-26 21-51-08](https://github.com/jupyterlab/jupyterlab/assets/5832902/2ee7b9e7-d357-4b7e-b5f3-4400fddb2c6d)


## Backwards-incompatible changes

<!-- Describe any backwards-incompatible changes to JupyterLab public APIs. -->
None

milestone.title: 4.0.x
milestone.description: Track issues than can be fixed and released in a post 4.0 release.

issue.title: The use of space in kernel/tab hierarchy should be improved

labels.name: tag:Regression
labels.description: Behavior that had been broken, was fixed, and is broken again

issue.body:
### Problem

I often use the "Kernels" panel of the "Running Terminals and Kernels" sidebar to re-open notebooks/consoles for kernels which are running in the background after closing the tab. This used to be rather straightforward in JupyterLab 3.x but got quite less convenient in JupyterLab 4.0:

| JupyterLab <4 | JupyterLab 4.0 |
|---|---|
|![image](https://github.com/jupyterlab/jupyterlab/assets/5832902/8cb91289-078d-4c80-a5c0-79787eb6d63f) | ![image](https://github.com/jupyterlab/jupyterlab/assets/5832902/e2feb88f-0982-48a8-82d9-bd4d5c1ec545) |

In both cases I closed the tab with `Unititled6.ipynb`; previously I could just click on it again in the "Kernels" section but now I need to:
- close the remaining two panels (and then)
- scroll back and forth to find it amid the repetitive "Python 3 (ipykernel)" grouping.

### Proposed Solution

Steps:
1. It could help if the kernels hierarchy auto-collapsed when a kernel has only one child. However, currently, when the hierarchy gets manually collapsed it is of little use
2. It could be handy to show both the kernel name and the notebook name in such cases
3. The repetitive part "Python 3 (ipykernel)" could be moved up to a new hierarchy level, so that each kernel group nests 1 or more kernels, and each kernel nests one or more tabs (main area widgets) attached to that kernel


| Step 1 | Step 2 | Step 3* |
|--|--|--|
| ![image](https://github.com/jupyterlab/jupyterlab/assets/5832902/72ae253b-394e-48bf-b0af-493a4b64a594) | ![image](https://github.com/jupyterlab/jupyterlab/assets/5832902/9b9b1ba5-069f-4402-8ec8-e05a8b3cfe03) | ![image](https://github.com/jupyterlab/jupyterlab/assets/5832902/47aa9f88-8076-41d4-8cd4-bda01e6924b8) |

\* Step 3 shows a slightly different but more representative situation where there are kernels of two different types, and where there are two notebooks attached to the same kernel.

<!---  ![image](https://github.com/jupyterlab/jupyterlab/assets/5832902/a6eb36be-3904-4017-ad12-29fc3a55e9b1) | -->

### Additional context

- https://github.com/jupyterlab/jupyterlab/pull/13851
- https://github.com/jupyterlab/jupyterlab/issues/13779

comment.body: @krassowski I'm working on several suggestions for a kernel and tab side panel refactor, brining together all the issues that have been opened on this subject. I have a question about your idea in step 3. What does the second level of drop-downs represent? What is the use case behind it? I'm not familiar enough with how kernels are used and what for.

issue.title: Bump mermaid 10.6.0, marked 9.1.2, rjsf 5.13.2

milestone.description: Milestone to track issues that will be released with JupyterLab 4.1.0.

issue.body:
## References

Fixes #15309

## Code changes

- [x] update js deps
  - [x] `mermaid 10.6.0` for bug fixes, performance, and new xychart
  - [x] `marked 9.1.2` for bug fixes
  - [x] `rjsf 5.13.2` for bug fixes
  - [ ] ???
- [ ] docs
  - [x] disable custom JS keyboard navigation in `pydata-sphinx-theme` (also raises warning)
  - [ ] ???
- [ ] ???

## User-facing changes

- large mermaid charts should render more reliably

## Backwards-incompatible changes

- n/a

pull_request.body:
<!--
Thanks for contributing to JupyterLab!
Please fill out the following items to submit a pull request.
See the contributing guidelines for more information:
https://github.com/jupyterlab/jupyterlab/blob/main/CONTRIBUTING.md
-->

## References

<!-- Note issue numbers this pull request addresses (should be at least one, see contributing guidelines above). -->
Fixes #14559

looking at the [basic setup](https://github.com/codemirror/basic-setup/blob/b3be7cd30496ee578005bd11b1fa6a8b21fcbece/src/codemirror.ts#L69) from CM, this adds also:
- [highlightSpecialCharacters](https://codemirror.net/docs/ref/#view.highlightSpecialChars)

There is one I'm unsure about:
- [highlightSelectionMatches](https://codemirror.net/docs/ref/#search.highlightSelectionMatches)

I'm not confident about that one as it won't work for notebook (only for file editor). And I guess the LSP extension as something better for it.

cc @krassowski

<!-- Note any other pull requests that address this issue and how this pull request is different. -->

## Code changes

<!-- Describe the code changes and how they address the issue. -->
Add CM extensions: `closeBracketsKeymap`, `highlightSpecialChars`

## User-facing changes

<!-- Describe any visual or user interaction changes and how they address the issue. -->
- Backspace between two brackets deletes both if auto closing option is on
- [Special characters](https://github.com/codemirror/view/blob/e6a55a6515521a84e709f02b4eb32e57aebbbfba/src/special-chars.ts) will now be highlighted with red dots, e.g. `­؜​‎‏  `

Before
![Screenshot from 2023-10-26 21-51-01](https://github.com/jupyterlab/jupyterlab/assets/5832902/751993e9-6897-4fb0-8846-ac9cd8485870)

After
![Screenshot from 2023-10-26 21-51-08](https://github.com/jupyterlab/jupyterlab/assets/5832902/2ee7b9e7-d357-4b7e-b5f3-4400fddb2c6d)


## Backwards-incompatible changes

<!-- Describe any backwards-incompatible changes to JupyterLab public APIs. -->
None

issue.body:
<!--
Thanks for contributing to JupyterLab!
Please fill out the following items to submit a pull request.
See the contributing guidelines for more information:
https://github.com/jupyterlab/jupyterlab/blob/main/CONTRIBUTING.md
-->

## References

<!-- Note issue numbers this pull request addresses (should be at least one, see contributing guidelines above). -->
Fixes #14559

looking at the [basic setup](https://github.com/codemirror/basic-setup/blob/b3be7cd30496ee578005bd11b1fa6a8b21fcbece/src/codemirror.ts#L69) from CM, this adds also:
- [highlightSpecialCharacters](https://codemirror.net/docs/ref/#view.highlightSpecialChars)

There is one I'm unsure about:
- [highlightSelectionMatches](https://codemirror.net/docs/ref/#search.highlightSelectionMatches)

I'm not confident about that one as it won't work for notebook (only for file editor). And I guess the LSP extension as something better for it.

cc @krassowski

<!-- Note any other pull requests that address this issue and how this pull request is different. -->

## Code changes

<!-- Describe the code changes and how they address the issue. -->
Add CM extensions: `closeBracketsKeymap`, `highlightSpecialChars`

## User-facing changes

<!-- Describe any visual or user interaction changes and how they address the issue. -->
- Backspace between two brackets deletes both if auto closing option is on
- [Special characters](https://github.com/codemirror/view/blob/e6a55a6515521a84e709f02b4eb32e57aebbbfba/src/special-chars.ts) will now be highlighted with red dots, e.g. `­؜​‎‏  `

Before
![Screenshot from 2023-10-26 21-51-01](https://github.com/jupyterlab/jupyterlab/assets/5832902/751993e9-6897-4fb0-8846-ac9cd8485870)

After
![Screenshot from 2023-10-26 21-51-08](https://github.com/jupyterlab/jupyterlab/assets/5832902/2ee7b9e7-d357-4b7e-b5f3-4400fddb2c6d)


## Backwards-incompatible changes

<!-- Describe any backwards-incompatible changes to JupyterLab public APIs. -->
None

comment.body: I agree that inclusion of `highlightSpecialCharacters` is a good call because it might help catch some security/correctness issues and likely has little overhead. I do not have a strong opinion on `highlightSelectionMatches` but I would worry that searching for selection could have slight performance penalty in large documents - I guess it could be exposed as disabled by default.

issue.title: Bump yarn to 3.6.4

issue.body:
<!--
Thanks for contributing to JupyterLab!
Please fill out the following items to submit a pull request.
See the contributing guidelines for more information:
https://github.com/jupyterlab/jupyterlab/blob/main/CONTRIBUTING.md
-->

## References

<!-- Note issue numbers this pull request addresses (should be at least one, see contributing guidelines above). -->
Maintenance to bump to the latest Yarn v3+

I stayed away from the new [v4](https://yarnpkg.com/blog/release/4.0). We may try it after JupyterLab 4.1
<!-- Note any other pull requests that address this issue and how this pull request is different. -->

## Code changes

<!-- Describe the code changes and how they address the issue. -->

comment.body: Something else to note here - with immutable builds the downstream extensions will need to refresh lock files after updating JupyterLab (even if they don't bump any npm dependencies). Not a huge pain but I saw reports of "this lockfile is different for me locally" because an earlier point release of yarn was shipped in JupyterLab RC phase.

pull_request.body:
## References

Fixes #15309

## Code changes

- [x] update js deps
  - [x] `mermaid 10.6.0` for bug fixes, performance, and new xychart
  - [x] `marked 9.1.2` for bug fixes
  - [x] `rjsf 5.13.2` for bug fixes
  - [ ] ???
- [ ] docs
  - [x] disable custom JS keyboard navigation in `pydata-sphinx-theme` (also raises warning)
  - [ ] ???
- [ ] ???

## User-facing changes

- large mermaid charts should render more reliably

## Backwards-incompatible changes

- n/a

milestone.description: Milestone to track issues that will be released with JupyterLab 4.1.0.

repo.name: jupyterlab
repo.description: JupyterLab computational environment. This is a very early preview, and is not suitable for general usage yet.

issue.title: `Contents.IDrive` / filebrowsers wishlist
issue.body:
<!-- Welcome! Thank you for contributing. These HTML comments will not render in the issue, but you can delete them once you've read them if you prefer! -->

<!--
Thanks for thinking of a way to improve JupyterLab. If this solves a problem for you, then it probably solves that problem for lots of people! So the whole community will benefit from this request.


Before creating a new feature request please search the issues for relevant feature requests.
-->

### Problem

Currently JupyterLab provides a way for third-party extensions to easily add extra source of contents via `Contents.IDrive`:

https://github.com/jupyterlab/jupyterlab/blob/97f1c6f957f272113dce8157318d74c4fb23c289/packages/services/src/contents/index.ts#L461

<!-- Provide a clear and concise description of what problem this feature will solve. For example:

* I'm always frustrated when [...] because [...]
* I would like it if [...] happened when I [...] because [...]
-->

### Proposed Solution

This is more of a meta-issue to track potential improvements and bug fixes to be done in JupyterLab to make the UX of working with drives more pleasant. Some existing issues:

- https://github.com/jupyterlab/jupyterlab/issues/14697
- https://github.com/jupyterlab/jupyterlab/issues/7755
- https://github.com/jupyterlab/jupyterlab/issues/15289

The documentation could also be improved to provide more guidance and visibility on the drive feature to extension authors: 

- https://github.com/jupyterlab/extension-examples/issues/215

In downstream applications drives can allow for additional content via a third-party extension:

- JupyterLite: https://github.com/jupyterlite/jupyterlite/issues/1041
- Notebook 7: https://github.com/jupyter/notebook/issues/6665
- Access remote contents: https://github.com/davidbrochart/jupyterlab-remote-contents

### Additional context

Example drives:

- https://github.com/jupyterlab/jupyterlab_collaboration
- https://github.com/jupyterlab/jupyterlab-github/
- https://github.com/jupyterlab-contrib/jupyterlab-filesystem-access
- https://github.com/jpmorganchase/jupyter-fs

---

Edited by @fcollonval: add jupyter-fs

issue.title: Cannot run alias defined in ~/.bash_profile in Terminal instance
issue.body:
<!-- Welcome! Thank you for contributing. These HTML comments will not render in the issue.

Before creating a new issue:
* Search for relevant issues
* Follow the issue reporting guidelines:
https://jupyterlab.readthedocs.io/en/latest/getting_started/issue.html
-->

## Description

When running instance of local installation of JupyterLab, bash aliases defined in `~/bash_profile`, are not available in Terminal instances.

## Reproduce

<!--Describe step-by-step instructions to reproduce the behavior-->

1. Define any alias in `~/.bash_profile`
2. Start installation of JupyterLab from local terminal with `jupyter lab`
3. Start Terminal instance in JupyterLab using Launcher (or from Classic view with 'New' > 'Terminal') 
4. Try to run defined alias

## Expected behavior

When running an bash alias in a terminal instance, I expect that it would be available.

NOTE:
- Output of `echo $SHELL` is `/bin/bash`.
- All environment variables `export`ed in `~/.bash_profile` are available in terminal instances.

## Context

<!--Complete the following for context, and add any other relevant context-->

- Operating System and version: macOS 13.2.1
- JupyterLab version: 3.5.3

comment.body: Hi @belkacemlahouel. No fix from my end, sorry. I have not been actively working on this issue though.

comment.body:
Hello,

For info I still encounter the same issue.

My use case is that I want to use !pip from Jupyter but it depends on an alias I have in ~/.zshrc = alias pip=pip3.
From my terminal it works fine, but not from Jupyter.

Any fix on your side @TidbitSoftware ?
